search_result.title: Cicadas myths debunked: You can eat them, and they don't bite
search_result.text:
This isn't one of THOSE years for cicadas in Iowa, where millions — maybe billions — of the bugs emerge after 17 years underground.

But cicadas in Brood X, one of the largest broods of periodical cicadas, are coming to the surface soon in Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania, Indiana, Ohio, and eastern Tennessee, and some may stray as far west as Iowa.

So now's a good time to remind yourself that the bugs may be big, loud and annoying, but they're not dangerous.

Here are common myths about cicadas, debunked.

More:Billions of cicadas are expected to emerge in the U.S. this year, but not in Iowa

Myth: Cicadas are locusts

When a mass of cicadas shows up outside their home almost as if overnight, some people associate the emergence, much like the Biblical plague of locusts, with a bad omen.

While cicadas might be colloquially called locusts in some parts, they're actually completely different species. Locusts are a type of grasshopper, while cicadas are a distinct insect type.

Locusts swarm in large groups much like cicadas emerge all at once. But locusts are much more damaging than cicadas, eating substantial amounts of vegetation and causing significant damage for local farmers. Cicadas, on the other hand, won't destroy crops and only feed on juices from trees.

More:Brood X: Why 'trillions' of cicadas set to emerge after 17 years have an ominous sounding name

Myth: Cicadas will harm you or your pets

Although it may look a little "Night of the Living Dead" when the ground starts bubbling up with emerging cicadas, there's no reason to panic. Cicada emergences are a natural phenomenon that has taken place for tens of thousands of years. Cicadas have been around since the age of the dinosaurs.

And they can't hurt you, said Elizabeth Barnes, exotic forest pest educator at Purdue University.

People tend to worry that cicadas will bite, but they don't have the mouthparts to do that, she said. Instead, they have a long, straw-like tube that they use to suck fluids from trees.

"They can't bite you, even if they want to," she said.

They also won't hurt your pets if they eat them, she said. In fact, many wildlife species will get nice and plump this year from all the extra protein. Sometimes, Barnes said, turkeys are even larger in the falls after a cicada emergence.

If your dog or cat is throwing up or acting sick, it's probably because they ate too many of them. That said, it's always a good idea to take your pet to the vet if you're concerned, she said.

Myth: Eating cicadas is gross

Although the idea of eating an insect may make some squirm, cicadas are a great source of protein and perfectly tasty, said Marten Edwards, a biology professor at Muhlenberg College in Pennsylvania.

For a cicada snack at peak deliciousness, Edwards suggests cooking a fresh one right after it emerges from the ground. At this point, the cicada will be pure white and soft before it hardens its shell, and there's less chance it's been affected by insecticide or other toxins.

More:Bugged by cicadas? Try walking around in your own personalized mesh pod

That said, if you're allergic to shellfish, you might want to steer clear. Purdue University entomologist Cliff Sadof explained that because insects are arthropods like shrimp or lobsters, there's a chance eating cicadas won't be good for you.

Myth: Cicada killer wasps are murder hornets

A type of wasp called a cicada killer or a cicada hawk feasts on cicada emergences, so if you live near an area of high cicada concentration, there's a chance you'll see these buzzing around as well.

With their striking black and yellow stripes, people will confuse them with infamous "murder hornets" that were sighted in Washington last year, Sadof said.

They're not the same, and they're probably going to leave you alone, Barnes said.

"We're trying to make sure that people know the difference between the two and not worry too much about them," she said. "It does hurt a lot if they sting you, but they're not aggressive ... these particular wasps, unless you directly threaten their nest, they should leave you alone."

Myth: Insecticides will keep cicadas away

Sadof said a major goal for the cicada team at Purdue this spring is preventing people from panicking at the sight of cicadas and then spraying insecticide all over the place.

More:Brood X is on the way: Here's how to keep cicadas out of your home and yard

There are too many cicadas to make an impact with insecticide, he said. During large emergences, there may be as many as 1.5 million cicadas per acre. Even if you kill a few cicadas, more will just take their place.

And remember, they'll only be around for a couple of weeks. Cicadas don't bite or sting, hurt your plants or your pets, so there's really no reason to try and kill them, Sadof points out.

Myth: Cicadas will keep you up at night

Cicadas can be loud — really loud. Some songs can reach 90 decibels, roughly the same level as a lawnmower.

Because of this, people tend to assume they'll keep them up all night, Barnes said, but that's not the case. Cicadas tend to mainly sing in the afternoon. If you hear the sounds of cicadas at night, it's probably just because a cicada was startled by something or it's the sound of something else entirely, she said.

Myth: Cicadas will hurt your plants

Possibly related to locusts' reputation for crop destruction, there's a common fear that cicadas will eat flowers, landscaping or vegetables.

They won't hurt your plants, Barnes said. In fact, they might help them. When cicadas die, their decomposing bodies have a lot of nitrogen in them, which makes for excellent fertilizer.

That said, if you have a small tree in your yard you might want to wrap it with mesh before the cicadas arrive. When they lay their eggs, female cicadas use a tool on their abdomen to saw a groove into the small twigs or branches. The result may cause those twigs to die. Large trees won't be too affected, she said, but small trees might need a little protection.

search_result.text:
It's a debut that's been 17 years in the making, and in a matter of weeks, it's one that will grab the attention of millions of Americans.

Billions of periodical cicadas will emerge across 15 states and Washington, D.C., with some possibly coming out as early as late-April or the first week of May, said Gene Kritsky, a periodical cicada expert and dean of Behavioral and Natural Sciences at Mount St. Joseph University in Cincinnati.

This year's group, known as Brood X, is the largest of the 17-year-broods in both density and geographical area. And while the name may sound dramatic, the "X" is technically the Roman numeral 10 in this instance, Kritsky told USA TODAY.

Read below for some of the most common questions surrounding these large, red-eye insects.

Visual guide: When will the cicadas emerge in 2021? How long will they be around after they come out?

Brood X:Why cicadas set to emerge after 17 years have an ominous-sounding name

'Zombie cicadas': They aren't a threat to humans. But they're killing each other.

Where will the Brood X cicadas emerge?

Essentially, there are three major patches where you're likely to see the largest swarms of these cicadas, Kritsky said:

The southeast corner of Pennsylvania, almost all of Maryland, parts of Delaware and New Jersey, and a few areas in New York.

Ohio, almost the entire state of Indiana, a few areas in eastern Illinois, and northwest and eastern parts of Kentucky.

Western North Carolina, east Tennessee and a scattering around west Tennessee and the northern part of Georgia.

Overall, this large emergence will affect the District of Columbia and at least parts of these 15 states: Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

When are the cicadas coming?

When soil temperatures hit 64 degrees a few inches below ground, the cicadas will start to emerge. That usually comes on the first or second day when temperatures reach the low 80s, Kritsky said.

"It's hard to make predictions other than just (looking at) long-term climate trends," Kritsky said. But generally, those temperature markers come earlier for Southern states. So northern Georgia could see the right conditions for Brood X emergence around the first part of May, while Cincinnati could reach that point near the middle of May.

But Kritsky said Brood X areas that see an unseasonably warm April could see the cicadas earlier than past years.

Brood X is on the way:Here's how to keep cicadas out of your stuff

Cicadas + lawn maintenance:Here's how to keep up your yard care during the Brood X emergence

How loud can a swarm of cicadas get?

While doing quadrant studies under a large oak tree, Kritsky estimated thousands of cicadas in the surrounding area. Standing a few feet away, he measured the insects' sounds at 96 decibels, slightly higher than a low-flying airplane, which can hit about 80 decibels.

"These individuals will crawl out every 17 years and they know they have only one purpose, and that is to mate and reproduce," said Jerome Grant, a University of Tennessee entomologist. "So they're going to make a lot of noise to attract females to mate."

Competitive males are all about flexing their muscles. That's how they make their trademark catcalls, Grant told the Knoxville News Sentinel, part of the USA TODAY Network. Male cicadas have a special ribbed organ called a tymbal. When they flex their muscles, the ribs rub together and produce sound.

Do people really eat cicadas?

Yes. There's evidence dating back to the 18th century showing people would eat the swarming insects, said Kritsky, who has tried them himself once. "I don't make it a habit of eating them."

"They taste kind of like cold, canned asparagus to me," said Grant, adding that they're best when harvested right after they've molted. "Then they're still soft. You can freeze them or cook with them. They make a good stir fry, and they're good in dumplings and in stews."

In 2004, the last time Brood X was swarming parts of the country, a group called the Cicadamaniacs at the University of Maryland released a cookbook filled with recipes for the bugs, including dishes like Soft-Shelled Cicadas, Cicada Dumplings and Cicada Stir-Fry.

Save room for dessert: The cicada cookbook, "Cicada-Licious," also includes recipes for chocolate chip cookies and rhubarb pie — each containing the special ingredient.

Contributing: Brittany Crocker, Knoxville News Sentinel

The rise of the Brood X periodical cicadas — those loud, large, kind-of-scary-looking insects that come out every 17 years — has begun in Louisville.

The early birds have been spotted in the area. But as temperatures rise at the end of this week – raising the ground temperature – the insects will come out in force. Within a few days, there should be an almost deafening buzz.

"Usually what you get is a week or 10 days of buildup, and then a few weeks of, sort of, peak activity, maybe three weeks, four at the most, and then it starts to dwindle," said Paul Cappiello, the executive director of the Yew Dell Botanical Gardens in Crestwood.

The cicadas will begin migrating above ground when soil temperatures reach 64 or 65 degrees, he said. That happens with atmospheric temperatures reach the 80s or 90s, which is expected this week.

The ground temperature in Bardstown on Tuesday was 72 degrees, with a low of 68 at around 4 inches deep, according to Kyle Wilkins, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service. He added that that temperature won't differ that much across the state, especially in Louisville.

The temperature at 20 inches deep is about 61, he said.

But having an air temperature increase and dry period over the next few days will definitely boost the soil temperatures, Wilkins said.

Here's what else you should know:

Related:Will trillions of cicadas ruin my spring? Maybe. How to prepare for the Brood X invasion

Where can I find Brood X?

You can see reported sightings in the area on the Cicada Safari app, developed by Mount St. Joseph University in Cincinnati.

According to the app, there have been heavy sightings of the bugs at Cherokee and Seneca Parks, the Strathmoor Manor neighborhood and near Brownsboro Road.

The U.S. Forest Service also has a map of cicada emergences.

Brood X will emerge this spring in 15 states, as well as Washington, D.C.

Washington, D.C.

Why are the cicadas emerging now?

We don't exactly know why the cicadas pick 17 years for their emergence cycle.

From underground, periodical cicadas have some method of counting the number of times deciduous trees – the kind that lose their leaves in the winter – regrow their leaves, said John Cooley, an entomologist at the University of Connecticut.

“The cicadas come out after the ‘right’ number,” he said. “Whatever the specific change is, the cicadas can detect that.”

The bugs will even, in unison, postpone their emergence for a day or two if the weather is rainy or otherwise uncooperative, he said.

Why are there so many?

Cicadas emerge in large numbers as a defense mechanism, Cappiello said.

Their predators include birds, snakes and other small mammals.

"Every animal has its evolutionary adaptation," Cappiello said. "The cicadas — it's just sheer numbers. There just aren't enough birds or raccoons or snakes to eat a couple billion cicadas in six weeks."

Can my dog eat cicadas?

The short answer is yes, but not too many.

Cicadas don't bite or sting, so the biggest issue for pets is overconsumption.

Gene Kritsky, a leading cicada expert and dean of Behavioral & Natural Sciences at Mount St. Joseph University, said it all depends on the pet.

"If the dog can't stop eating them, it could lead to bowel obstruction," Kristy said.

The exoskeleton of the cicada is undigestible, he said. Some pets might eat one or two and should be fine, but others may eat too many, which would lead to issues.

"In most cases, your dog will be fine after eating a few cicadas," American Kennel Club chief veterinary officer Dr. Jerry Klein said in an article for the organization. "However, dogs that gorge on the large, crunchy insects will find the exoskeleton difficult to digest and can suffer serious consequences."

How long do cicadas last?

They'll likely be active through June, bumping into your windows and terrorizing anyone outside.

Expect this brood to be noisy. That buzzing is a mating call.

"Adults climb the trees beneath which they developed or fly to new trees where males serenade females with cacophonous songs only appreciated by another cicada," Joe Boggs of Buckeye Yard and Garden Online said.

For subscribers:Do you have a right to work from home? Here's what legal experts say

Periodical cicadas can also damage trees and woody ornamental bushes.

Females slit twigs to insert batches of eggs after mating. Those twigs break at these weak spots and are left to dangle, turn brown and die, according to University of Kentucky officials.

This “pruning” can adversely affect the developing structure of small trees but is typically OK for large trees. Cappiello recommends covering smaller trees with bird netting to prevent the cicadas from accessing the branches.

When will the cicadas die?

If the weather is consistently warm and dry, the cicadas will finish their mating activities sooner than later, which would mean a shorter season.

Their lifespan is four to six weeks, and they will start to die off in late June into July.

The nymphs, however, will be hibernating and maturing for the next 17 years. We'll see Brood X again in 2038.

However, other broods in Kentucky will emerge before Brood X returns. We should expect to see the insects in different parts of the state in 2024, 2025, 2029, 2031 and 2033.

search_result.title: Cicadas arriving: What are they? Can they bite or sting? What to know.
search_result.text:
After hanging out underground for 17 years, a new brood of periodical cicadas has officially popped up in people's backyards.

This year, a group of cicadas known as Brood X is expected to appear in the District of Columbia and at least parts of these 15 states: Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

Gene Kritsky, a periodical cicada expert and dean of Behavioral and Natural Sciences at Mount St. Joseph University in Cincinnati, told USA TODAY cicadas would emerge when soil temperatures reached 64 degrees. Kritsky predicted they'd arrive in late-April or early May, which seems to be the case for some Americans.

Already people are posting photos and videos of cicada sightings in their backyards and homes. Dr. Beverly Howard photographed her twin granddaughters taking a closer look at a group of cicadas near her home in Burke, Virginia.

As this year's batch of cicadas start swarming parts of the country, USA TODAY is breaking down the latest updates and tips you need to know.

What are they?

This group of periodical cicadas, called Brood X, have been feeding on sap from roots of plants underground for the last 17 years. After emerging, they will spend two to four weeks "courting, mating, flying, driving people crazy, being eaten by everything" said Michael Raupp, emeritus professor of entomology at the University of Maryland.

The cicadas will lay their eggs which will hatch 4 to 6 weeks later. Then their offspring will repeat the cycle and head back underground until 2038.

While above ground for the next weeks, cicadas will be loud. Raupp said they can emit sounds between 80 and 100 decibels, equivalent to a low flying airplane or a lawnmower.

What do we know about them?

Kritsky said when cicadas emerge from underground, they will appear white. Once they shed out of their old skin and develop an exoskeleton, their yellow and black color will appear.

As for the loud noises they make, males are the only ones who can create the noise. They do so when they're calling for other females to mate. The intensity of the noises should decrease within two weeks, Kritsky said.

Once the mating process is over and eggs are hatched, the cicadas die and their offspring will repeat the cycle. Female cicadas can hatch up to 500 eggs, Kritsky said.

Although they don't swarm in packs like bees, Kritsky said cicadas do congregate in the hundreds around trees.

Will you spot a cicada?:Cicada swarms are coming to a state near you. Here's what to know

How can we track them?

Funded through Mount St. Joseph University, Kritsky created a crowdsourced app, Cicadas Safari, where people can send in photos of the cicadas they find. The app is free, and Kritsky said once someone downloads a photo, the app tracks the location to verify the latest cicada sightings.

Are they dangerous?

Kritsky said cicadas don't sting or bite. If an animal or dog eats a few dozen cicadas, Kritsky said it will be okay. However, if they eat hundreds of cicadas in one sitting, the animal may experience bowel obstructions.

"They're just going to drink sap and mate. They won't eat your plants or carry away small children," Kritsky said.

What should I do if they're in my yard?

"If you see a group of cicadas, you've got to just let cicadas be cicadas," Kritsky said.

The bugs don't have pads to pick up pesticides like cockroaches do, so bug sprays won't work, Kritsky said. He also mentioned cicadas won't affect anyone's gardens or plants because they don't chew on things.

They do drink sap from trees or stems. If you'd like to protect a small tree, Kritsky recommends wrapping it in a protective layer. If you're still looking to protect your garden and plants, you can create a physical barrier around them. If your plants or bushes are damaged, you can revive them with extra water and mulch.

search_result.title: Invasive species: 5 insects decimating NJ environment
search_result.text:
Invasive insects from other parts of the world threaten the balance of New Jersey's ecosystem.

As non-native species, invasive insects do not have any natural predators in the area and if left unchecked can have a significant impact on the environment. Their damage costs the state $290 million in agricultural losses annually, according to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection.

Thousands of non-native species have been brought to the state over the years either intentionally or by accident.

"Many of these species are benign while others, such as agricultural crops, are highly beneficial," the DEP stated on its website. "However, a small percentage have caused severe damage to our environment and to our health."

Story continues below gallery

Here are five invasive species that have caused the most damage to the Garden State over the years:

Spotted lanternfly

The spotted lanternfly, a colorful, Asian plant hopper, made its way to New Jersey in 2018 from Pennsylvania. It is known to feed on the bark, leaves and sap of more than 70 plant and tree species, including willows, maples, poplars, tulip poplars, birch and ash. Eight counties are currently under quarantine due to the lanternfly: Warren, Hunterdon, Mercer, Somerset, Burlington, Camden, Gloucester, and Salem.

"We currently have 13 crews of two who are out searching for and scraping egg masses and will be treating areas when the spotted lanternflies begin hatching in early May," a New Jersey Department of Agriculture spokesperson said in a statement sent to NorthJersey.com. "We are enlisting the help of the state’s citizens to helps us eliminate this insect as much as possible, now through egg mass scrapings and later through treatments on their properties."

The lanternfly's feeding stresses plants and hurts their ability to heal and can kill the trees.

The bug was first discovered in the U.S. in 2014. It has since spread to New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, New York, Connecticut and Ohio. The NJDA is researching natural predators for the lanternfly to control its population.

Emerald ash borer

This beetle has destroyed tens of millions of ash trees throughout the U.S. and Canada. It was first seen in New Jersey in Somerset County in May 2014. It has made its way to Bergen, Burlington, Camden, Essex, Gloucester, Hudson, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Passaic, Somerset, Sussex and Warren counties since then.

The ash borer once caused Morris County to chop down 10,000 ash trees as a safety precaution. It's believed to have first come to New Jersey on wooden packing materials from China.

Nine percent of New Jersey's forested areas, mostly in the northwestern part of the state, were threatened by the emerald ash borer.

"The department has been releasing egg and larval biocontrol parasitoids against this insect in ash stands throughout the state since 2016 to help curb the spread of the emerald ash borer," the NJDA stated.

Environment:NJ's unequal rules put some at greater risk of drinking lead. These families pay the price

Khapra beetle

These beetles are native to India. They stow away in grain and seed.

"Previous U.S. detections of this tiny beetle have required massive, long-term and costly control and eradication efforts," the U.S. Department of Agriculture stated.

They do better in hot weather but are survivors, resistant to many pesticides and able to go a long time without food.

The khapra spoils much of stored grain and seed products where its found from its feeding, per the USDA.

Longhorned tick

The first longhorned tick was found in New Jersey in 2017 but could have been in the state longer.

Native to China, Korea and Japan, longhorned ticks are tiny and can infest a wide range of animals, from dogs and cats to livestock and wildlife. It is unknown how much of a threat it is to humans. One was found on a Bergen County girl in 2018.

The tick has been confirmed to be in Bergen, Camden, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Passaic, Salem, Somerset, and Union counties in New Jersey. This tick is unique because it is asexual and does not need a mate to reproduce.

Gypsy moth

The gypsy moth is one of the oldest invaders, released into the United States in Massachusetts in 1868. It made its way to New Jersey a half-century later and has been feeding on tree leaves since. More than a million acres of trees have been damaged by gypsy moths since 2007, prompting the state to spray insecticides from planes on wide swaths of forest.

New Jersey started a suppression program for the moth in the 1970s. The NJDA recommended 170 acres in the state for gypsy moth treatment in 2021, down from 4,500 acres in 2018 and more than 100,000 in 2008.

Gypsy moths threaten oak, maple, birch, beech, willow, and hickory trees. The larger caterpillars also have been known to feed on pine, spruce, hemlock, and many common ornamentals, per the NJDA.

Coffeehouses are like gas stations. They provide fuel.

Tea rooms are more like spas. They offer a chance to slow down, socialize and reflect.

Tea house owners generally do not object if you'd like to pull out your phone to document the photogenic sandwiches and sweets. It's the 21st century, after all.

Hettich and other tea house owners say they pay more attention to their customers' comfort than to nit-picky rules about what and what not to do when taking tea.

"Our goal is to make you feel like you're sitting at home with your grandma," Hettich said. "It's warm and comfortable."

Still, there's no denying that taking afternoon tea feels more formal than the lunch breaks to which most of us are accustomed.

"We're go-go-go, right?" said Sara Peterson, who manages Teaberry's in Flemington, which is owned by her mother, Susan. "Just to sit down, with beautiful food, served in courses, is like a mini-vacation."

If you do feel awkward when faced with a tea strainer or another tool of the trade, rest assured that the wait staff at a tea house is ready to assist you, without judgment.

"We get a lot of Girl Scout troops, and some of these children have never seen a fabric napkin before," said Vicki Weiss, owner of Mathis House in Toms River. search_result.title: Indian River's 2nd referendum: Teachers' jobs at stake
search_result.text:
Gray Hughes

rghughes@dmg.gannett.com

If the Indian River School District referendum does not pass, Superintendent Susan Bunting said jobs will be cut.

For Bunting, not having teachers in front of kids is not an option.

"Right now, I am feeling excited about the holidays but when we get back in January we will hit the ground running," Bunting said. "Although we are off, our minds are working full time."

According to Bunting, if the referendum does not pass, 10 percent of district jobs could be cut, which would equate to 20 paraprofessionals, 10 custodians, seven and a half secretaries, five administrators and, most importantly to Bunting, 90 teaching positions.

Bunting added not all teachers cut would be classroom teachers — many who are on teacher contracts are either specialists or helping with response to intervention — and the last people to be impacted will be the teachers who are in the classroom every day.

BACKGROUND: Indian River referendum fails in razor-close vote

The average student might not be impacted at first, Bunting said, but after a while the changes will become noticeable.

"If you have one less custodian in your building, maybe the building isn't quite as clean," she said. "A student might not notice a big difference for a year or two until you have to postpone buying textbooks for a few years or postpone repairs to technology."

When the Indian River School School District Board of Education voted to approve a second referendum on Dec. 14 during a special meeting, they voted to keep the referendum at 49 cents, with 33 cents for student enrollment growth. However, school security was reduced from 10 cents to eight cents, and textbooks, technology and student organizations were combined into one category, tentatively called "student services and support," and would receive eight cents.

If passed, it would raise $7.35 million for one of the fastest growing school districts in the state. Indian River's student population has grown by 22.4 percent over the last 10 years.

Indian River Chief Financial Officer Jan Steele explained school safety was reduced and student services and support were increased due to the State of Delaware looking to cut $15 million in public education, which would in turn cause the Indian River School District to lose $900,000.

"One of the suggestions is to cut education sustainment funds from each district, which we use to pay local salaries," Steele said. "We would then need to come up with local salary funds based on the state cuts."

Despite the most recent Indian River School District referendum's failure to pass, referendums in Delaware have had recent success.

BACKGROUND: Indian River board approves second referendum

After failing to pass the first time, a referendum in the Brandywine School District passed on May 16 to raise funds for the operating budget as well as money for a capital funds project. The referendum was approved by voters 5,780 to 3,720.

The Appoquinimink School District recently passed two referendum measures to build a new school and to raise money for teacher recruitment and retention, technology and other expenses. The capital project referendum passed by a margin of 5,506 to 2,102 while the referendum for operational funding passed 5,152 to 2,496.

Even with the recent success of referendums in Delaware, not all residents are happy to see another one on the table.

"I have a bad feeling about it," said Mark Warrington of Selbyville. "I'm all for the kids but this would adversely affect those of us on a fixed income."

Bunting added she and the district will make more of an outreach to inform wary citizens.

For example, senior citizens can qualify for a tax break and not see any difference in taxes, she said.

"We have talked about going to senior citizen centers and having conversations there," Bunting said. "If we can go and talk to people and answer their questions we can ensure they are not operating on misconceptions and we can get them to understand the situation and get them to be more empathetic."

Bunting said concerns have also been raised due to the audit report released by the Delaware Office of Auditor of Accounts just five days before the previous Indian River School District Referendum. The report detailed financial misdoings by the district and former Chief Financial Officer Patrick Miller.

The district has been working with the auditor's office, and Bunting hopes the office will give the district a letter of support.

"We are working with them to verify we are making changes," she said. "And we want to be able to document those changes."

The district will cut costs even if the referendum does pass, Bunting said.

"I often liken our situation to your home situation," she said. "If your budget gets tight or an unexpected expense arises, you start to look around and see what you can do without or wait another year to purchase. We are going to start to do that now."

The district will also be utilizing social media more than ever to help get the message out, Bunting added.

For Bunting, the referendum is ensuring students are properly served in the school district and there is no change in the operations of the district.

"I hope the public will see the need that our kids have," she said. "We are up about 300 children from Sept. 30. We continue to grow and we need more of everything."

search_result.title: Christina School District takes third try at referendum
search_result.text:
Saranac Hale Spencer

The News Journal

Christina School District is trying for a third time to convince voters to allow it to raise taxes.

Two other districts, Brandywine and Cape Henlopen, are seeking increases through referendums this month.

But Christina is doing so after its last two tries were rejected by voters.

In the March 23 referendum, the district is asking for an increase of 30 cents per $100 of assessed value – about 20 percent less than what it asked for last spring. The district expects that, if voters approve, it will bring in over $16 million.

That money, school officials say, is sorely needed after the district slashed its budget by $9 million when the last referendum failed, said Brian Stephan, co-chair of the district's referendum steering committee.

"We're already running at bare-bones level," he said.

Christina is hoping to replace some of the 78 teachers and 14 aides that were laid off in the budget cuts. Those layoffs led to larger class sizes, and the district is aiming to get back to its pre-2015 class sizes, said Wendy Lapham, spokeswoman for the district.

If voters reject the referendum for a third time, there's nothing left in the heftiest part of the budget to cut, Stephan said. The salaries and benefits of school workers take up 85 percent of revenues, and that section has already been shaved down. The district would have to cut after-school activities, after-school transportation and extracurricular activities, he said. The "nuclear option" would be closing down some school buildings.

Following the defeat of the last referendum, Stephan said, the district took the temperature of voters to see what their hesitations were. In response, it lowered the proposed tax increase this time around, which it estimates to be about $192 per year for the average homeowner.

Christina School District gears up for second tax vote

If it passes, Christina is planning to set aside $1 million to improve the general school environment – how exactly that will be done is still open for debate, and the district is having a public meeting on March 15 to discuss approaches. It will start at 7 p.m. at the Gauger-Cobbs Middle School on Gender Road in Ogletown.

Brandywine hasn't pitched a referendum since 2012, and it is asking voters later this month to approve a 28-cent increase to school tax bills in order to finance the general operational needs of the district. Along with that, in a single vote, it is asking for voters to fund a capital project and a special project that would resurface several school athletic fields with synthetic turf.

The turf project would take three years to fund at 5 cents per $100 of assessed value, and the whole project, which would cover athletic fields at three schools, would cost about $5 million, said Superintendent Mark Holodick.

The capital project would cover work on three school buildings and the demolition of a school that has been empty since 2010. It would cost local property owners just over $19 million, but it wouldn't actually increase the taxes they've been paying because it would pick up where a large capital project, passed in 2005, left off. That was a $63 million project that renovated two schools, built three new ones, demolished one, relocated the district office and purchased a transportation facility, Holodick said.

Cape Henlopen is putting up a capital request to build two new elementary schools and renovate two old elementary schools, which is the last phase in a 20-year, long-term plan that the district committed itself to in 1999.

It asked for a 17-cent tax increase for the district's operating budget in 2014, said Superintendent Robert Fulton.

Cape Henlopen needs the new schools to accommodate growth, he said – it has gotten more than 1,000 new students since 2001.

The state is paying $72 million toward the project if local taxpayers will shoulder about $48.5 million.

With the growth that district has had, if it doesn't get new buildings, it would have to add modular classrooms, Fulton said.

That growth is "a good problem to have," he said. "We're just trying to plan ahead."

More holidays are on the way for many, but it's still business as usual in education throughout the state.

Make Us Visible Delaware hopes to spur more support for Asian American history to infuse in K-12 education. Also, Delaware public schools are looking for state funds to help with capital projects and deferred maintenance. For one district, that's some 29 buildings that will feel impact.

Another event aims to spur interest in Asian American history for Delaware schools

Make Us Visible Delaware just launched this fall, under the mission to push for more Asian American history in Delaware's K-12 curricula.

Now, it seems the group hopes to build community support.

MUV plans to host an engagement event Saturday, Dec. 9, discussing these efforts, offering resources and more. The event will run from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Sanford School in Hockessin. Register ahead or learn more online.

State approves school funding requests for building projects, Red Clay eyes referendum

Delaware Department of Education approved several requests for state funding next fiscal year. The department green-lit 50 certificate of necessity requests last month, while 44 involved state funding.

From new Appoquinimink elementary, middle and high schools, to a new Charles W. Bush Early Education Center in Brandywine or renovations to over 20 Red Clay schools — which project funding districts hoped to secure can be explored online. search_result.title: Brandywine students seek money to play Carnegie Hall
search_result.text:
Ken Mammarella

When the Brandywine School District Orchestra plays Carnegie Hall April 10, it’ll do many things.

It’ll demonstrate the growth of district orchestral programs. “We’ve progressed so far,” said senior violinist Deirdre Buckmaster.

It’ll make memories. “I’ve never experienced anything like that,” said sophomore cellist Isaiah May.

It’ll be “big and exciting,” said senior violinist Harrison Dennett. “It’s a really cool opportunity.”

And “it’ll show people what we can do,” said sophomore violinist Mackenzie Pile.

The invitation came about last year when orchestra director Anita Pisano asked junior cellist Isabel Stone to name her dream gig. And it follows what might have been the death of the orchestra when a tax referendum failed before a second attempt passed.

About 30 of the orchestra’s 70 members, from Brandywine, Concord and Mt. Pleasant high schools, have committed, but the cost of nearly $1,000 per student is a stumbling block for others.

Pisano said students have held fundraisers and “sold as much as we can.” They’re crowdfunding via CheddarUp.com and Concord Friends of Music. A send-off concert is planned March 28 at the Grand.

Fundraising chair James R. Hanby Sr. hopes “these students have an opportunity I never had.” He played the violin in elementary school and 30 years ago helped try to start a district strings program.

It’s not just the joy of performance. He told the story of Edna Turner Bradfield, who as leader of the Wilmington Orchestra House in decades past, said “music can help a pupil in algebra.”

Donors so far, Pisano said, include the principals of all three high schools, the Brandywine Education Foundation, Richard Donner, Joseph and Judith Setting, New Castle County councilman Bob Weiner and state Sen. Cathy Cloutier.

Besides the prestige of being selected for Carnegie Hall’s Symphonic Series, the students are also seeing the Statue of Liberty and “Aladdin,” with a bonus backstage tour.

“The whole trip is about playing on that stage and being better at what we do,” Pisano said. “By performing together, we grow closer as a family. I’ve had some (students) since sixth grade and seen them grow.”

At first, students were pulled out of other classes for lessons, but that evolved into classes in each high school.

“It’s been incredible to watch and share their personal experiences,” she said.

When the strings program – violin, viola, bass and cello – was scheduled for fiscal elimination last year, Pisano planned a thematic program that included Dvorak’s “New World Symphony” and Haydn’s “Farewell Symphony.”

“It was a very moving concert,” she said. “A nice way to say goodbye.”

A second tax referendum passed, and the orchestral program survived, so the Carnegie Hall and Grand concerts include this symbolic trio: Chesnokov’s “Salvation Is Created,” “Jupiter, the Bringer of Jollity” from Holst’s “Planets” and highlights from “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”

For the last piece, district STEM coordinator Judson Wagner led makerspace students into creating bows that resemble light sabers, via wiring, coding, 3D printing and laser cutting.

“This is where music and technology converge,” the Brandywine Bow Project tweeted.

To make it all happen, Pisano said she did a lot of research about the companies that book performances at Carnegie Hall. She selected Manhattan Concert Productions because it “was the most reliable, with the best background and strongest recommendation.”

To be accepted, she had to submit recordings of the ensemble (one last fall, another this month) and background information about the ensemble and the schools.

The firm says “each participating ensemble will receive written and recorded critique by nationally recognized clinicians as well as a private clinic session with one of them.”

“It’s a master class, basically,” Pisano said. “We’ve been through a bunch of bumps and bruises, but we have grabbed that energy and are able to perform as a family.”

GHelp

The Brandywine School District Orchestra plans a concert at 7 p.m. March 28 at the Grand, 818 N. Market St., Wilmington, called “A Little Night Music and Carnegie Send-off,” according to Lauren E. Conrad, Concord High’s director of choral music. Funding for the Carnegie Hall experience is sought through CheddarUp (www.cheddarup.com/tabs/brandywine-school-district-orchestra-foundation) and Concord Friends of Music, care of Concord High School, 2501 Ebright Road, Wilmington, DE 19810.

search_result.text:
Jessica Bies

The News Journal

Consultant: $300M required to support port growth

The state-owned Port of Wilmington will need up to $300 million for new warehouses, cranes and land to keep up with growing demands over the next two decades, according to a master plan that lays out options for future growth released Monday.

The blueprint calls for more investments from private sources and is the next step in a long-running discussion about how to grow the critical shipping economy.



"All the numbers you saw today are big. They are all a challenge to a state that has significant budget constraints. So if we are going to expand in a significant way, we are going to have to partner with other investors," said Delaware Secretary of State Jeffrey Bullock, chairman of Diamond State Port Corp., the public-private board that oversees the sprawling complex.

Read more here.

16-year-old boy shot in Wilmington

Wilmington police responded to the 1000 block of N. Lombard St. on Monday night to find a 16-year-old boy had been shot in his right leg.

The victim was treated at the scene by New Castle County Paramedics and transported to the Nemours/A.I duPont Hospital for Children Emergency Room in good condition.

The investigation is ongoing.

Anyone with information in reference to this shooting, which happened at about 7:58 p.m., is asked to call Detective Pete Leccia at (302) 576-3647.

Residents nearby stood and watched the scene.

“When you hear one shot and somebody got hurt, that’s personal. That hits close to home. I’m ready to leave here,” said nearby resident Zillah Edwards, who was home planning her wedding when she heard the shot.

More here.

Delaware Memorial Bridge lost $204,544 after lane closures

Last month's traffic nightmare produced by three days of Delaware Memorial Bridge lane closures resulted in $204,544 in lost toll revenue, the agency that operates the span said Tuesday.

Three lanes on the 3,650-foot Delaware-bound crossing were closed April 19-21 after inspectors found 2.25- and 2.5-inch support cables connecting the roadway to the bridge needed to be fixed immediately. Only the far right lane was left open.

Motorists endured delays of 2½ to 4 hours in backups stretching up to five miles on Interstate 295.

The Delaware River and Bay Authority said 93,476 vehicles did cross during those days, but that's a 27 percent decrease from the prior year.

"If you want continued repair and maintenance on the bridge, you got to do what you got to do, and there's just inconvenience," said DRBA Commissioner Richard W. Downes on Tuesday.

Read more here.

Brandywine district's second referendum is Tuesday

The Brandywine School District is putting up a referendum on Tuesday asking residents to approve a tax increase of 28 cents per $100 of assessed property value to support its regular operating budget, plus approve funding for a special building project.

It will be the second time this year that the district has gone to voters with those proposals – the last time they were paired with a plan to install synthetic turf fields at some schools. All three of those proposals – for a tax increase to support the regular operating budget, for funding to cover the cost of the building project and for money to install synthetic turf fields – were bundled together in a single vote that was rejected by a very slim margin in March. The district decided last month to present the same plan again, without the synthetic turf project.

Districts can go out for a referendum twice in a one-year span, according to Anthony Albence, director of the New Castle County Office of the Board of Elections. Last year, the Christina School District was in a situation similar to the one Brandywine is in now – its first bid for an increase in taxes to support its operating budget failed, so it went out for a second one. That one failed, too. But, this past March, Christina got its 21-percent tax increase passed.

Brandywine has a $174 million budget for the next school year, but will have to slash $8 million if the referendum doesn't pass, according to Superintendent Mark Holodic

Del. sues massage parlors owner in prostitution sting

Delaware prosecutors are suing the owner of four massage parlors who was caught in an undercover police investigation into prostitution in 2014.

The lawsuit filed Friday seeks $700,000 in civil penalties from Smyrna resident Da Zhong Wang, 52, for violating state racketeering laws. It also seeks to stop Wang from owning and operating massage parlors in Delaware.

Wang, a Chinese citizen living in the U.S. on a work permit, previously owned Relaxed Spa in Rehoboth, Massage Center in Middletown, Wang's House of Acupressure in Smyrna and Da Wang's Bodyworks in Dover, the lawsuit said.

In November 2013, an undercover Delaware State Police trooper visited the Middletown location. The masseuse offered the officer a sex act during the massage, the lawsuit said.

Read more here.

Wilmington mayor, council president release budget compromise

Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams and City Council President Theo Gregory announced Monday they've agreed on staffing reductions, funding inefficiency studies for two departments and money for the city's land bank.

The proposal will be vetted by the Finance Committee on Monday at 5 p.m. and is scheduled to be voted on Thursday by the full 13-member City Council.

According to a news release, the $154 million budget now is $613,000 lower than the budget proposed by Williams in March.

Gregory said in a statement: “We were able to eliminate some positions which will produce longer term savings, identify new funding for the land bank and other neighborhood-based housing projects and we found money so we can finally move forward with departmental management studies to help us become a more efficient government. Budgets are all about compromising and that’s what we’ve done in this case.”

Read more here.

Bill would guarantee public defenders for juveniles

Top Delaware lawmakers want to guarantee juveniles have access to a public defender, regardless of family income or the level of their alleged crime.

The state Office of Defense Services already offers free legal representation to young people facing charges, even though it's not required by state law. House Bill 382 seeks to set the policy in stone so that future budget cuts or changes in leadership don't change that.

Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth Beach, who sponsored the legislation, said in a statement, "We can’t rely on current practice as a guarantee for the future."

The change, if approved, would mean the courts and Public Defender's Office will be required to continue the practice.

"This legislation takes the small but important step of codifying an existing practice so going forward there is no question that minors being charged with a crime in our state have the same rights to public defenders as adults," said Senate President Pro Tempore Patricia Blevins, D-Elsmere, lead sponsor of the bill in the Senate.

Read more here.

Lenore Matusiewicz dies while serving life sentence

After years of high-profile schemes and court battles over her grandchildren, Lenore Matusiewicz has quietly died in a Texas prison.

Matusiewicz, whose late husband fatally shot their former daughter-in-law at the New Castle County Courthouse in 2013, was sentenced to life in prison on harassing and stalking charges just three months ago.

The 71-year-old died at the Federal Medical Center Carswell in Fort Worth, Texas, on May 6, according to a Federal Bureau of Prisons online inmate locator. A cause was not immediately available.

Lenore Matusiewicz's brother, Tom Kula, told the Associated Press he was notified of her death May 7.

She had been in ailing health since being sentenced in February by a federal judge who took the unusual step of conducting the hearing at her bedside at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia.

Thomas Matusiewicz opened fire on their ex-daughter-in-law Christine Belford and her friend “Beth” Mulford as they walked into the New Castle County Courthouse lobby for a child support hearing with David Matusiewicz on Feb. 11, 2013. David is Lenore and Thomas's son and Belford's ex-husband.

The federal government accused Lenore Matusiewicz and her children – Newark optometrist David and nurse Amy Gonzalez – of waging a campaign to harass, torment, stalk and spy on Belford and the couple's three daughters in the three years leading up to Belford's death.

Read more here.

Police identify construction worker on I-95

Police have identified the man fatally struck Monday night on I-95 northbound in the Wilmington area as 36-year-old Aleksandr Y. Mitishov, according to Delaware State Police.

A police investigation determined that the crash occurred around 7:34 p.m. when Mitishov exited the driver's seat of a 2014 Ford F-350 parked on the right-hand shoulder of I-95 on the Brandywine River Bridge, south of U.S. 202, police said.

Mitishov, who was employed by Enterprise Flasher Company of Wilmington, was preparing to set up construction warning signage and was wearing a reflective vest when he stepped out into the right hand lane of travel, police said.

He was then struck by the right side front of a 1998 Nissan Quest, driven by Victor M. Sitiriche, 35, of Wilmington, police said.

Read more here.

The Power of Food TV on Delaware chefs' careers

Can an appearance on a national TV culinary show change your life?

Yes, it can.

Just ask Newark pastry chef Dana Herbert, winner of “Cake Boss: Next Great Baker,” a TLC pastry competition program hosted by star baker Buddy Valastro.

Herbert, who took home the title in December 2010, says the series gave him a national platform that showcased his baking and decorating skills. It also helped the University of Delaware graduate expand his thriving custom cake making business and eventually open a Newark dessert shop. And Herbert has been crowned with lifelong celebrity chef status.

“It definitely changes things,” says the Bear resident. “What TV does, it puts a stamp on what you’ve already been doing. It introduces you to people that are outside of Delaware, and even inside Delaware. It really gets you out there and gets you known for what you loved doing.”

search_result.title: Delaware schools struggle with proposed cuts
search_result.text:
Jessica Bies, and Matthew Albright

The News Journal

Educators and parents are up in arms over $37 million in budget cuts to public schools proposed by Gov. John Carney and vow a fight in the General Assembly to stop them.

"At some point in time, we have to look at our future and stop robbing Peter to pay Paul," said Jeff Day, who is running for a spot on the Christina school board and has children in the Appoquinimink district.

Carney has said he would rather not be making any cuts but said "shared sacrifice" is necessary in the face of the state's nearly $400 million budget deficit.

"These are extremely modest cuts in the scheme of things, and other cabinet agencies are being cut a lot more," Carney said. "All we're asking is that our school boards do a little more to run a little more efficiently."

STORY: Standoff ends in Middletown; suspect in Delaware trooper death killed

STORY: Fear spreads through Middletown-area neighborhood

The cuts are only 1.5 percent of the state's $1.37 billion public school budget, the governor noted.

About $15 million of the cuts will come straight from school districts' operational funds, money that generally isn't used to pay teachers but covers training, technology and other administrative costs.

An additional $22 million will come from something called the "education sustainment fund," which is used for a much wider range of services like math and reading specialists, after-school programming and paying staff salaries over the summer, before tax receipts come in.

Carney's plan would allow districts to make up the $22 million cut by giving school districts a one-time shot at raising property taxes – without asking their voters in a referendum. It would need the approval of the General Assembly.

That would leave only a $15 million cut spread over the entire system, the governor reasons.

But school board members say the decision to raise that so-called "match tax" would put them in the painful position of losing money or outraging taxpayers at a time when many school boards already are struggling to pass referendums.

School board members also say the property tax increases would unfairly burden taxpayers in property-poor districts.

“It’s foolish, I think, and a fool’s errand when the state is facing a big deficit like it is, to argue the state shouldn't cut education," Appoquinimink school board President Richard Forsten said. “Times are tough and everyone needs to tighten their belts … but if we’re going to do it, it needs to be fair.”

A tight timeline

The General Assembly has until June 30 to debate the state budget, and school districts have only until July 13 to get tax warrants to their local counties, giving them little time to ponder a final decision on the match tax.

The dilemma for superintendents and principals is that state law mandates any teacher laid off must be notified no later than May 15.

STORY: Carney proposes tax hikes, spending cuts in state budget

STORY: Delaware's budget hole deepens by $35.6 million

Districts will need to plan for cuts they aren't even sure are coming. That means they might be sending pink slips to employees they might not need to fire.

Conversely, the cuts may deepen and they may have dip into their reserves or get rid of school programs.

Rep. Melanie George Smith, D-Bear and chair of the budget-writing Joint Finance Committee, acknowledges the timing is tough for districts. But she said it's too early in the General Assembly to give a final ruling.

Lawmakers still have to settle the thorny question of how much to cut and how much to raise revenue. Carney has proposed an equal balance of tax increases and spending cuts, but lawmakers don't have to follow that rule.

While there's little appetite among lawmakers to balance the budget with nearly $400 million in tax increases — thus avoiding cuts entirely — they could lean a little heavier on taxes than Carney did. They could expand Carney's proposed increases to the income tax, corporate franchise tax and tobacco tax. Or they could impose other hikes, like expanding the lodging tax or adding to the alcohol tax.

That could mean the proposed cuts to education would vanish or diminish.

This revenue issue is perhaps the biggest question looming over the current General Assembly. And Smith said her committee won't know how to handle education cuts until that question is answered.

"We on JFC can't say what we're going to do until our 62 colleagues decide what kind of revenue we have to work with," Smith said.

She said it's also possible her committee will find other, less painful places to cut education spending.

"The question isn't how much we're cutting; the question is what we're cutting," she said. "We can find places to cut spending that don't affect direct instruction."

But "there really are no easy answers here," George cautioned.

If state government were to avoid education cuts, it would have to make deeply painful cuts elsewhere. Education makes up about one-third of the budget.

The only other part of government that is anywhere near that size is health and social services, on which the state spends about $1.1 billion.

Story continues below graph.

Schools have been taking up a greater share of the state budget each year because state officials are required by law to increase funding as the number of students in public schools grows. As a result, the number of education employees in Delaware has grown significantly even as the number of other government workers has declined.

STORY: Gov. John Carney: Fix budget, update Coastal Zone Act

In 2009, there were 16,877 school district employees — as of this February, that number had grown to 19,422. During the same period, the number of other state government employees shrank from 14,103 to 13,338.

While Carney has insisted he does not intend for schools to cut staff, salaries are the biggest part of every district's budget. Which has several of them looking at layoffs.

To tax or not to tax?

The cuts are worse if school boards don't impose the referendum-less "match tax."

For instance, Christina School District is estimating total losses of about $5.86 million — $3.9 million of which it could potentially recover via the match tax.

That means raising taxes 7.3 cents per $100 of assessed property value. For example, a home in Windy Hills, Newark, recently sold for $224,000 has an assessed property value of $63,700 and would face a potential annual property tax increase of $46.50, according to district records.

In comparison, Christina’s last referendum, held in 2016, raised taxes by 30 cents, an increase of about $191 per year on a similarly valued home.

Even if the district ultimately decides to raise taxes without voter approval, it still would have to make about $2 million in cuts, according to Christina Financial Manager Bob Silber. Due to timing considerations, it's also making plans for the full $5.9 million.

Causalities could include the district's Montessori Program, which has an enrollment of about 60 students and was recently re-committed to by the school board. Another option is to discontinue elementary instrumental music and elementary and secondary string music classes.

The cuts seem large, but for some school districts, reductions are compounded by the fact they already planned on making large ones next year.

Take Indian River, which days before Carney released his budget had outlined $1.72 million in reductions.

Though it recently passed a $7.35 million referendum, the district has been struggling financially and planned on reducing the amount of paid coaching staff for athletics and some salary reductions, including eliminating non-athletic extra pay for extra responsibilities.

The plan was to streamline programs, not eliminate them. But now, with Indian River facing a total of about $3.4 million in cuts, the scope of that original budget reduction plan could change. Passing the “match tax” would raise taxes about 12.5 cents per $100 of assessed property value, Superintendent Mark Steele told residents during a recent "town hall" held on Facebook Live.

STORY: Colonial takes another shot at referendum, warns of cuts

STORY: Indian River School District faces $3.4M in cuts

For Colonial, which is holding a referendum June 6, there's even more on the line.

The district's last referendum, in February, was voted down, which means the district was already considering cuts.

Should the June referendum also be defeated, Colonial is preparing to implement over $4 million in reductions for the 2017-2018 school year, including 120 layoffs. The budget cuts add roughly another 50 layoffs, bring the total to 170.

Those estimates are based on the total cuts the district could see in the budget — about $3 million — and does not include the match tax.

"The idea of the referendum is really to make us whole," Colonial Superintendent Dusty Blakey said. "To keep us at our operating level currently."

Shared sacrifice

Other school districts, like Appoquinimink, are approaching the education cuts a little differently. The district is considering reducing transportation costs, reducing its budget for substitute custodians and eliminating up to 17 teachers, among other things.

Forsten, the school board's president, seems to realize cuts, if not inevitable, are likely. He's trying to prepare for them.

He and the district's financial director, Charles Longfellow, are working to ensure that even if the district has to raise taxes, it's doing so in a way that's fair to local residents.

Because the way Carney has proposed doing it, that's not fair, Forsten said.

He said because the cuts aren't based on districts' property tax bases, some Delaware homeowners will have to pay only a little bit more in taxes each year, while homeowners in districts like Appoquinimink would shell out a pretty significant chunk of change.

Forsten used Brandywine, which like Appoquinimink is facing about $3 million in total cuts, as a comparison.

If Brandywine and Appoquinimink both had to cover the total $3 million, he said, the taxes in Appoquinimink would be higher.

In Brandywine, a home valued at $63,700 would face annual property tax increase of about $56. In Appoquinimink, where rates needed to be raised more because there's less taxable property, taxes will go up by about $95.

Forsten thinks the formula for calculating the cuts needs to be changed, so residents all pay roughly the same.

At a board workshop Wednesday night, not all agreed.

Christina's Day says instead of suggesting changes to how the cuts are made, school boards throughout the state should be rallying against any cuts at all.

"Don't roll over, acquiesce and say, 'Yes, Dover, if you give us the authority to match tax, we'll use it,'" Day said. "Otherwise, they'll just keep doing this."

He also thinks resources given to school districts should be the same across the state, and that Appoquinimink should be fighting to eliminate the cuts altogether instead of looking out for its "best interests" and making sure it doesn't have to pay significantly more in taxes than Brandywine or Christina.

"I think we should be fighting so that all kids in the state are not hurt by this budget," Day said.

search_result.title: Delaware has bigger problems than school district consolidation
search_result.text:
Matthew Albright is The News Journal's engagement editor. Contact him at malbright@delawareonline.com, (302) 324-2428 or on Twitter @TNJ_malbright.

In an utterly unsurprising turn of events, a task force that studied the possible consolidation of school districts is — drumroll please — not recommending a plan to consolidate school districts.

That's going to annoy many Delawareans.

The News Journal is constantly getting calls, letters and comments saying "why don't we just consolidate school districts? How about they stop wasting my money before they ask me for more?"

I'm all for taxpayers viewing government spending skeptically. And it does seem a little out of whack for a state that's shorter than 100 miles long and has fewer than a million people to have 19 different districts.

But the cost savings from consolidating school districts would be much smaller than most people think. They certainly would not be worth the political slugfest it would take to make consolidation happen.

The main problem has to do with teacher salaries, which are by far the largest part of the education budget. Teacher pay varies between districts — for example, a Colonial School District teacher with four years or less earns an average of $41,235; the average Brandywine School District teacher with that experience earns $45,923.

If you merged those two districts into one, you'd have to equalize the pay. No superintendent or lawmaker's going to cut teacher salaries, so you'd have to raise pay for hundreds of teachers.

We're talking millions of dollars in raises.

You might ask: "But what about all the excess administrators you'd get rid of?" The fact is, there simply aren't that many administrators running around in Delaware school districts.

There are more than 9,506 teachers in Delaware, but there are barely 1,000 administrators. And that includes principals and assistant principals, who are a vital part of schools.

Administrators make up less than seven percent of education salaries.

Could school officials streamline some administrative positions and save some money on the margins? Maybe, and they should always be looking for ways to do that. But you simply can't cut enough administration to defer a referendum or put a ton of new money into some other program.

Eliminating districts would also be messy and controversial.

You might have to change feeder patterns for schools. You'd have to change staffing, move some schools to new curricula, work out bus routes and rework facilities to meet district standards. You might have to close some schools.

All of this would be an enormous disruption to students, families, teachers and everybody else in the merged systems. There would inevitably be a big fight, whether it's in school boards or the General Assembly.

If we're going to have a big fight over education, let's have it over something with more concrete benefits — like weighted funding for high-needs schools, or improved teacher training and development, or, as the task force suggested, re-assessing property taxes to eliminate arbitrary tax inequities. But redistricting as a means to save money isn't worth the political capital.

I happen to think there are non-fiscal reasons to redistrict in some cases. Most notably, it's unconscionable that Wilmington is torn into four different districts, all of which also have significant suburban populations. There's no district dedicated to tackling the unique problems that come with high-poverty, inner-city schools.

But, as the Wilmington Education Improvement Commission proved when its redistricting plan failed in the Senate two years ago, suburban residents don't want to take on the challenges that would come with adding those high-poverty schools to their districts. It's near impossible to pass such a plan through the General Assembly.

Delaware should definitely explore ways to make its school districts work more efficiently, and the consolidation task force explored some interesting ideas. Even if they don't consolidate districts, lawmakers and superintendents could consolidate some back-office functions, like finance, transportation management, and human resources.

Cost-effectiveness should always be part of Delaware's school conversation. But we should stop tying ourselves up in knots talking about consolidation.

When it comes to schools, Delaware has much bigger fish to fry.

search_result.title: School board elections: Most incumbents keep seats
search_result.text:
Matthew Albright

The News Journal

Like most years, turnout was tiny, and most incumbents kept their seats in school board elections up and down Delaware on Tuesday, according to unofficial results from the county Departments of Elections.

There were 24 seats open across 16 school districts, but a third of those never came to a vote because some were uncontested and one saw no candidate file at all.

Almost all incumbents defeated their challengers, if they had any. Only Colonial’s Ronald Pierce lost his re-election bid, getting 93 votes to Margaret Lucille Kennedy’s 140.

Competition was fiercest in the Cape Henlopen School District. Challenger Jose Saez got 1,206 votes – the third-highest tally of any candidate in the state – but fell short of unseating Roni Posner, who brought in 1,330. Jason Bradley, who ran for a different seat on Cape Henlopen’s board, racked up the most votes of any candidate, defeating Gary Wray 1,564 to 679.

Brandywine also saw relatively high turnout, with Kristin Pidgeon defeating Arthur Kirksey 1,000 to 163 and Karen Gordon beating Diana Hanby 995 to 270.

Those contests saw far more voters than most, however. Only seven candidates statewide got more than 500 votes.

The most crowded field was a seat open in Appoquinimink, but Michelle Myers Wall easily surpassed the five other candidates, garnering 609 votes.

School boards set the direction for their districts, managing multimillion-dollar budgets, hiring and firing top school leaders and signing off on major programs like Race to the Top.

They are also the bodies that choose to initiate property tax referendums, asking voters to increase taxes to fund their districts’ operations.
