search_result.title: DuPont, Chemours risks deepen concern about economy, jobs
search_result.text:
Jeff Montgomery

The News Journal

It was late December when DuPont Co. announced the unthinkable: As part of its split into two companies, it would move about 800 DuPont employees out of its Wilmington headquarters into the suburbs this summer, while moving an equal number of white collar staff for its Chemours spinoff into its historic building downtown.

Chemours will take on DuPont's worldwide Performance Chemicals division. Its formation also will create a watershed moment for Delaware, which owes its original manufacturing and science-based identity to the company – and where the company as recently as 1979 directly employed more than 1 out of every 10 working residents statewide.

Stakes are high for Delaware's already strained economy and the tax base of its largest, and deeply troubled, city.

There's already worry that Chemours could be gobbled up by DuPont competitor Tronox Inc. soon after the split, which would likely take any headquarters choices out of the new company's hands, and weaken Delaware's ability to shape the decision.

"The deal that TROX clearly wants to do is the (highly strategic) acquisition of Chemours once DuPont spins off that business to shareholders mid-year," said Ian Corydon, an analyst and co-director of research for investment bank B. Riley & Co.

Tronox, the formerly bankrupt spinoff of Kerr-McGee Corp., is the world's largest fully integrated producer of titanium ore and titanium dioxide. DuPont is the global leader in total output of the same valuable pigment, but will spin off that business to Chemours, including its Edge Moor plant, the oldest in the company's worldwide fleet of "TiO2" production centers.

Wilmington Councilman Charles M. "Bud" Freel, who chairs the city budget committee, said he's already hearing that Chemours could be a short-term tenant in downtown Wilmington, and that some DuPont workers might already be moving out.

"From everything I've heard or even read, there's no guarantee that the Chemours people are going to be there for any length of time," Freel said. "I understand they're talking to other cities about a new location."

Wilmington has a 1.25 percent earned income tax that plays a huge role in its annual operating budget. If it loses the white-collar jobs in a block-long building downtown, the loss would open a giant hole in the city's budget.

"Even if they do move some of the Chemours people in," Freel said, "I don't think you're looking at the same salaries that the DuPont folks who are moving (out) are being paid."

DuPont spokesman Dan Turner said Friday that company moves already are "under way and will be complete by July 1." DuPont's portion of the original enterprise will be headquartered at its Chestnut Run complex at Lancaster Pike and Centre Road, while Chemours will take ownership of the DuPont Building at 10th and Market streets.

"We are working to move employees to and from each location to ensure a smooth transition," Turner said.

Asked about Tronox and a potential early takeover bid for Chemours late Friday, Turner said only: "We do not comment on rumors or speculation."

Losing those jobs would be another blow to Delaware's once-leading status as a place for high-income, high-tech research jobs. While Delaware is making progress in replacing those jobs, some fear the state is losing ground.

William R. Latham III, a University of Delaware associate professor of economics, said the First State is entering a new economic era that will demand adaptability.

"I don't think you can take a perspective and say, 'What are we doing wrong? We're witnessing the evolution of the economy and a particular industry," Latham said. "Because Delaware is so small, we're more aware of the effects of particular industries and particular companies."

The shifting landscape has resulted in growth among smaller tech firms. Hundreds now work in different high-tech sectors at what was once DuPont's former diagnostics technologies site in Glasgow, south of Newark. Big employers include bioscience leader Siemens Health Care Diagnostics and Holologic, Inc., a major global producer of crucial devices for mammograms.

ANP Technologies Inc., a Newark biotech company launched in 2002, now has 30 workers and Department of Defense approval to create a handheld device for sensing bio threats. But ANP founder Ray Yin says more needs to be done to keep the local tech sector thriving.

"My personal wish list, as someone with a high-tech company, is to have the state paying more attention to helping companies market their products, or provide some marketing resources," Yin said. "Once we have marketing and sales down, that means we have to produce more and hire more people."

State officials said they're listening. Gov. Jack Markell said they're exploring options like direct aid, employer recruitment and developing new and expanded education and training for entry-level workers in fast-changing, technology-intense workplaces. He also pointed to employment gains that have steadily bested the region and national average over the past several quarters.

"We need to keep the foot on the pedal," he said.

Delaware also will do all it can to keep Chemours in Wilmington, said state Economic Development Office director Alan Levin.

When the DuPont split is complete, Chemours worldwide will have 9,100 employees. "One thousand of them, or close to a thousand, will stay here in Delaware," Levin said. "Our intention is to make sure they stay permanently. I don't think it's panic button" time.

Even success in holding on to Chemours would be a far cry from 1990, when DuPont employed 27,000 across Delaware, from its "Nylon Capital" plant in Seaford to its research center along Brandywine Creek.

By 2001, the number had plunged to 12,400, and fell about 50 percent more, to estimates of around 8,300, by late 2013.

Chemical manufacturing by all companies, meanwhile, dropped by two-thirds between 2002 and mid-2014, from 7,000 jobs statewide to about 2,632. Those manufacturing losses were part of a broader trend that included the recent shutdown of Chrysler and General Motors plants in New Castle County, sites that employed about 10,000 in 1980 and 5,000 at the start of the last decade.

Compounding the workforce pressures has been a more-than 70 percent drop in "management of companies" jobs lost as Delaware-based corporations streamlined and industries consolidated – a roughly 15,000-position drop between 2001 and 2014. By way of comparison, that reduction is only slightly smaller than the state's entire construction workforce, but with a higher average weekly wage.

"People who were in middle management and making $120,000 a year now can find only jobs making $60,000 or $70,000 a year," said A. Richard Heffron, president of the Delaware State Chamber of Commerce. "There is a (national) recovery. Things are getting a little bit better. But it's not quick enough."

Edward Ratledge, who directs the University of Delaware's Center for Applied Demography and Survey Research, said much of the change has been profound and, likely, permanent.

"It's hard. When you look around, what it looks like is small business is where the action is. Big businesses are getting smaller all the time because they're the ones able to replace labor with capital," Ratledge said.

"With the hollowing out of the middle-skill jobs, what happens is that some people with a little more education can climb in to higher tech groups. But the rest are left fighting for the lower up to the middle skill jobs, and that drives wage rates down."

In 2012, Delaware's per capita personal income dipped below the national average for the first time since at least 1929, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. That indicator, used as one measure of economic well being, remained at the second-lowest all-time level relative to the national average in 2013, although the state average has increased in each of the last three quarters.

And while individual industries have varied widely, the state's average hourly wage declined from $22.67 in June 2010 to $21.81 in June 2014.

In July, the Chemours headquarters team will occupy aging office space vacated as the original company moves to its new Chestnut Run complex on State Route 141.

Of 37 sites worldwide, the new Chemours firm would have only two production locations in Delaware, along with its initial headquarters and two research and development activities to be leased in the DuPont Experimental Station northwest of Wilmington.

Chemours also would take on the Chambers Works fluoroproducts plant in Deepwater, N.J., at the foot of the Delaware Memorial Bridge, and operations in Elkton, Md.

There are other possible headwinds. "They're coming downtown and people forget: That's an older building," Heffron said. "I've talked with people over there and there are some problems with the fact that it is an older building."

DuPont, in fact, only recently built two new, ultra-modern buildings at its headquarters destination at Chestnut Run, part of a Wilmington-area office modernization that the company dubbed "Project Renaissance" – years before the split was announced.

Chemours, Heffron said, "could be anywhere." While Chemours in Wilmington is a goal, keeping them in Delaware is paramount.

"The other thing is, as companies become smaller, they become more attractive to other companies for a takeover or merger, and we've seen what that does," Heffron said. "You lose control."

Frederick C. Sears II, chairman of the Wilmington Economic and Financial Advisory Council, which produces city revenue estimates, said that the new company's payroll and permanence are concerns.

Yet Sears also noted that other big buildings in the city once filled with DuPont workers have since been taken on for new activities and jobs, many in the financial services industry.

"All those buildings have since been filled with other folks," Sears said.

Levin also believes it wise to take the broad view.

"I think what you need is a diverse workforce in a lot of ways. Good-paying jobs are important, but you need a diverse workforce that can weather storms," he said. "If we have all our apples in the financial services basket and financial services takes a hit, then we take a bigger hit. So we need to spread things out in some ways."

New and advanced technology and information technology fields are a high priority. Markell and state officials last week announced a new "Pathways to Prosperity" workforce training effort, focused on computer science, engineering, bioscience, culinary arts, hospitality management and manufacturing logistics.

Administration officials also point to solid gains in some technology areas, ranging from market victories by companies already here to new arrivals.

Examples include a decision by growing biopharmaceutical company, Incyte, to locate its corporate headquarters in the renovated John Wanamaker department store north of Wilmington, and ILC Dover's relocation of Grayling Industries from Mexico to Seaford, where a new containment products plant is expected to employ 115.

Although direct manufacturing employment remains in decline amid a continuing workforce shift toward service industries, the number of people employed in scientific research and development has turned up since its 2010 low, reaching about 6,850 people in 2013. But those jobs are more spread out, in smaller firms, with the number of research and development job sites increasing to 98 statewide in 2013 compared with 66 sites a dozen years earlier.

Much of that growth is a testament to the ambitious and growing Delaware Technology Park in Newark, where about 800 people now work in dozens of research and start-up enterprises supported by an array of private business partnerships, government programs and higher education institutions.

In June, the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation, an eight-year-old think tank based in Washington, D.C., ranked Delaware second among all states for its moves toward the "New Economy." The group singled out the state as the "most globalized," and for gains in research and development investment and high wage jobs in production of goods distributed outside the region or globally.

"Over the course of the last 10 years, we've seen about 80 companies come up from scratch to some substantial levels" said J. Michael Bowman, president of Delaware Technology Park, a cluster of laboratories, cutting edge research and advanced technology business incubators just north of Newark Shopping Center. "The more we do that, we become somewhat of a magnet for bringing others in from other areas."

Bowman is also associate director of the University of Delaware's Office of Economic Innovation and Partnerships.

The park houses the University of Delaware's Biotechnology Institute's Bioimaging Center, a maze of modern research tools. In one of the center's rooms, University of Delaware biology graduate student Katie Minker peered at images of corn leaf cells infected with a fungus, using a kind of microscope that eliminates unfocused, less useful light and improves details when researchers are using materials to make tissue details fluorescent.

The system was one of an array of exotic imaging systems, some individually costing more than $1 million, that the University operates at the Bioimaging Center at DTC, making them available to dozens of users on a cost-recovery basis. Resources include a super-computer and 3-D imaging theater.

"Science is really shifting. Gone are the days when an investigator had every tool they wanted in their own lab," said Jeffrey L. Caplan, the center's director. "We now have to share."

Bowman said the center is itself a research and economic development magnet, making the area more attractive to both scientists and scientific entrepreneurs.

Near Glasgow, global giant Air Liquide has been building a major research and technology center since 2007 that employs about 100 in high-tech gas, membrane and semi-conductor sciences and industry work. A neighboring company, Hologic, produces 55 percent of all the digital detectors used in three-dimensional mammography machines.

"Detectors made in Delaware show up in Russia, in Thailand and all over the U.S.," said Jim Culley, director of strategic projects for Hologic Inc. "We have about 150 people in Delaware – six or seven Ph.Ds and most of the rest are engineers."

Hopes are high, too, for UD's Science, Technology and Advanced Research (STAR) campus, which has emerged as a leading symbol of Delaware's reach for post-recession, new economy growth.

The 272-acre former Chrysler assembly plant site was acquired for a range of academic, research, industry and incubator uses, and already hosts fuel cell-maker Bloom Energy's factory and a new UD Health and Science Complex.

SevOne, a 400-employee, growing Newark-based, global network management company, recently signed a 13-year lease for space at the campus as well, supported by a $1 million grant that also will help add to its Delaware workforce.

Delaware Technology Park and Delle Donne Associations – a commercial developer of 18 of STAR's acres – recently announced an agreement for a new, 10,000 square foot portion of a new building for specialized laboratories for use by startup companies.

Several miles away, along the Delaware River in Newport, an Air Liquide subsidiary called Medal employs about the same number of people making specialized membrane devices to separate gases and liquids at nano-scale levels.

The company's systems are in use to produce nitrogen from air bled off the engine of airborne Boeing 737, the F-22 Raptor and other aircraft that is then used in fuel tanks, to reduce the risk of explosions.

"We'll make the little hollow fibers the size of a human hair with holes in them by the gazillion miles, then assemble them into membrane elements. Then we can go further into complete systems," said Charlie Anderson, director of biogas technology and advanced separations solutions for Air Liquide. "We sell a lot of stuff into China. It's very difficult to make, what we do."

It is far from replacing all the jobs once generated by DuPont. But the company's split – and potential departure of Chemours – is a point Delaware was bound to reach, Levin said.

"It's a global corporation now. They're still an integral part of Delaware, but by the same token, they've had to spread their production workforce all over the globe," Levin said. "This was bound to happen eventually. It's not that DuPont has gotten smaller. DuPont has just taken a different turn, if you will, to be a global company and not a Delaware company per se.

"They're still here. We're very proud of that and we're going to do everything we can to help them grow."

The University of Delaware's Latham also saw Delaware arriving at this crossroads.

"If you look at the fact that employment in Delaware is not doing badly, that's a positive," Latham said. "We've managed to hold on to a lot of employment" despite losses of business that once dominated the economy."

"The startups that we're looking at now are frequently a handful of people, but if you can have a thousand of them and the total employment is what you have from one large manufacturer, that can make a difference," he said. "I think we need to have the flexibility in our arrangements that make Delaware an attractive place for new kinds of industry."

search_result.title: Trump country: Delmarva's Trump voters send message
search_result.text:
Matthew Albright and Jeremy Cox

USA Today Network

Hillary Clinton won Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, but the Delmarva Peninsula is Donald Trump country.

Northern New Castle County and Rehoboth Beach in Delaware and Northampton County in Virginia are packed with voters who favored Clinton. But, geographically, the peninsula still sports a sea of "Trump-Pence" signs, and many rural residents proudly wear hats that say "Make America Great Again."

Only a few miles separate metropolitan residents from their small-town neighbors, but the 2016 election that will place Trump in the White House made it seem like urban and rural residents live on different planets.

"It has really made me question what kind of country I live in," said Andrea Wallace, a Newark resident and proud Clinton supporter. "I just thought there was no way somebody like [Trump] could win an election."

Clinton garnered 2,112 more votes than Trump on the Delmarva Peninsula, but voting fell mostly along urban-rural lines.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

RELATED: After Trump win, where do we go from here?

RELATED: Two rallies for peace on UD's campus

Trump voters say liberals are seeing their candidate through a funhouse mirror, distorted by their own prejudices and biased media coverage.

Many Delmarva residents believe Clinton, rather than Trump, is the serial liar. Trump's business acumen is irrefutable, no matter how often liberals point to his half-dozen bankruptcies and the more than 4,000 lawsuits involving him and his businesses, conservatives contend.

Trump's income tax proposal saves its biggest cuts for the nation’s richest families, reducing the top federal income rate from 39.5 percent to 32.2 percent. But supporters see Trump as a savior to the working class.

“When you take away people’s ability to make a decent living in this country, you’re going to have an uprising,” said Rosanna Nicoletos, 60, a real estate appraiser from the retiree community of Ocean Pines in Worcester County, Maryland. “The only thing that matters is people want to make their own way in this world. And we get labeled the tea party or that party. These are just people who want to make a better way for their family.”

Trump's fans believe he will “bust up” endemic corruption inside the Beltway, no matter how much the New York Times writes about him proudly avoiding paying taxes for nearly two decades.

They think he is the one to heal divisions between Democrats and Republicans, no matter how much Democrats decry him smearing his rivals as “crooked” and “lyin’.”

Trump’s charged comments about blacks and Latinos shattered political norms, prompting Clinton to call him a racist to his face. But in the largely white, rural quarters of the Delmarva Peninsula, that's just Democrats and their friends in the media conflating political correctness with the moral high ground.

"People got angry with the media because they were so overwhelmingly supportive of Hillary and her campaign and so negative to the point that people just turned their TVs off and wouldn't even listen," said Michael J. Harrington Sr., a real estate agent who lent an open storefront in downtown Dover to the Trump campaign. "We just want somebody who will tell the truth."

A darker economic reality

The rural-urban divide is intensifying nationwide. Experts like University of Delaware professor Ted Davis argue those two worlds are facing very different realities, particularly when it comes to economic development.

Rural hospitals in critical condition

"You go to rural areas, the economy is still very depressed," Davis said. "You can almost feel it in the air."

During the Great Recession, rural economies fell apart earlier than their urban counterparts and were slower to rebound.

Rural employment began to fall after the first three months of 2007, a full year before urban employment began to sink, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s economic research office. Both showed signs of recovery through the first half of 2011. Afterward, urban areas continued to improve while places outside major cities stagnated.

The researchers attribute the employment gap to lower population growth in rural areas and an older, less-educated workforce.

As of September, New Castle County’s unemployment rate stood at 4.3 percent. In rural Wicomico County on Maryland’s lower Eastern Shore, 5.1 percent were looking for work.

In Dorchester County, home to Maryland's third-highest unemployment rate, Trump romped to a 55-41 percent victory over Clinton. In one precinct Trump's lead was 78 percent to 19 percent.

Bernadette Sahm, who splits time between Lewes and Baltimore County, worries about the world her three grown children are inheriting.

“I don’t feel the American dream is as attainable for them with housing prices being up and wages being down," said Sahm, 57, the former head of the Smyrna Opera House who now runs a consulting business for nonprofits. "The jobs aren’t as good, and it’s sad."

STORY CONTINUES BELOW MAP

View a larger version of the map below.

It wasn’t easy being a Trump fan in a blue state, Sahm said, because Trumps speaks his mind.

“I get that he can be abrasive to some people," Sahm said. "But he’s from New York. I’m Italian. In my family, you just tell it like it is.”

Davis argues the Republican's supporters were willing to overlook some of his controversial remarks and flaws as a politician because Trump was more clearly articulating a grim reality they were experiencing. While Clinton did talk a lot about creating jobs, she stuck to President Barack Obama's playbook and painted a picture of growth rosier than that experienced by people in rural areas.

"The thinking is, we're having economic hard times, and the Democrats didn't seem to address this," Davis said.

In the days before the election, Democratic pundits were gleefully wondering whether Trump had destroyed the Republican Party. On Nov. 9, they had to face a reality that the GOP will control the White House, both houses of Congress and soon the Supreme Court.

Republicans also expanded their dominance at the local level, seizing full control of 33 state legislatures and 33 governorships.

This harsh reality has led to many Democrats questioning their leadership — on Thursday, Ohio Rep. Tim Ryan announced he would be challenging California Rep. Nancy Pelosi's position as minority leader. Many Trump voters say the Democrats had it coming.

“I think most people in the country were just sick of Washington," said Darin Mister, a 21-year-old Salisbury University student and Somerset County native. "They wanted change. Hillary’s been the ultimate Washington insider forever. We need something different."

Mister said Trump represented something new while Clinton appeared to be from a world long since past its expiration date.

Dallas Collins, an 80-year-old retiree in Laurel, believes Democrats have spent too much money on welfare programs, arguing that liberal politicians are simply handing tax dollars to urban residents.

He may live less than two hours away from Wilmington, but Collins admits the city's ways and thinking are foreign to him.

“It’s just a difference in the area,” Collins said. “You have more farmers, a lot more working people. You have people up there who are on welfare and need help and all. Once people get on free stuff, it gets to be a habit; you stay on it.”

Racial and social change

One of the things that terrifies Democratic voters the most about Trump is how he has talked about race, ethnicity and religion.

Trump's decision to name as his top adviser Steve Bannon, the former publisher of the incendiary right-wing website Breitbart, drew swift condemnation from many Democrats.

"Mr. Bannon personally has made despicable comments about women, the LGBT community, people of faith, and those with mental illness," U.S. Sen. Chris Coons, D-Del., said in a statement posted on Facebook. "At Breitbart, Mr. Bannon created an outlet built upon stoking racism, sexism, homophobia, and anti-Semitism."

As a candidate, Trump called for a ban on Muslims entering the U.S., and some of his aides have recently discussed the possibility of a "Muslim registry." A crackdown on illegal immigration was the centerpiece of his campaign, and many Latino advocates said the way he talked about immigrants was racist.

Trump said during one debate that African-Americans were "living in hell," a statement many black leaders decried.

"I knew there were still racists out there, but I thought we were past the point where we would elect somebody like this," said Mike Gregory, a Bear resident who is black. "It scares me. A lot."

Trump supporters say liberals and the media twisted Trump's words and misrepresented his policies to make him sound like a racist. They argue a call for tougher enforcement of illegal immigration does not equal a hatred of immigrants.

"He's not going to stop Mexicans coming into the country, he's just going to do a better job screening them, which is what we should be doing," said Harrington, the Dover real estate agent. "And when people talk about these refugees, he's just saying we need to be totally sure we're not letting bad people in who are going to harm our country. Hillary just wanted to let them all come in, and I think she just did that to get votes."

Davis, the University of Delaware professor, says many rural voters are troubled by the rising share of minorities in the U.S. population, and by the change in social norms to things like marriage and gun rights. That's partially because most migration and rapid social changes have historically happened mostly in cities, so urban voters are more accustomed to the changes.

"I'm not saying that [urban residents] are over it, but they've had to deal with multiculturalism for more than a century in the big cities," Davis said.

Mister, the university student, shakes his head at exit polls showing how his generation, the millennials, voted in large numbers for Clinton. As millennials age, they will join his camp, Mister predicted. And they shouldn’t be labeled as racists or xenophobes for doing so, he said.

“That’s all from the media, social media in particular," he said. "That’s where most people get their news these days. The large majority of the things you find on social media are very left."

The culture wars are not limited to issues of race. Many Trump voters, like 57-year-old Dorcester County resident Mark Marshall, were afraid Clinton would take away their guns.

He watches enough MSNBC to know what the liberals are thinking: Why does he need a gun in the first place?

He has a collection of guns, lifting his sweater for good measure to show that he has one tucked into his waistband.

“Why do I need a pickup?" Marshall asked. "It’s my life. I choose to live it the way I live it. And you choose to live it the way you live it.”

search_result.title: Why Delaware plays the corporate welfare game
search_result.text:
Scott Goss

The News Journal

DuPont Co., JPMorgan Chase and Amazon are vastly different companies that share at least two things in common.

They are among some of the largest companies in the United States.

And each has pocketed millions of dollars in Delaware taxpayer grants for promising to stay or expand here.

“In some cases, the money is less than what these companies earn in a single day,” said former state Finance Secretary David Singleton, who also spent 15 years as JPMorgan’s managing director. “But it’s still a good chunk of money, and it’s coming out of our pockets.”​

Economists, retired corporate executives and former state leaders say those incentives are seldom the deciding factor in where companies choose to put their resources. They also question whether the investments pay dividends in the long run.

But they all agree it’s a game Delaware – and other states – must play if they want to attract corporate jobs because no state can afford to back out now.

“Look, everybody does it so we have to do it, too,” said Jim Butkiewicz, who heads the University of Delaware’s economics department. “It may not be the easiest fact of life to accept, but it’s a reality of economic development today.”

How Delaware outhustled other states to win DuPont ag unit

So why does Delaware and practically every other state in the country award money to corporations that rake in billions of dollars a year?

“It’s not because the companies need [state help],” said Timothy Bartik, a senior economist at the W.E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Research in Kalamazoo, Michigan.

“But in the highly competitive world of economic development, [corporations] are perceived as having location options and, therefore, leverage,” he said. “As a result, governors and mayors throughout the country are afraid of the political and economic consequences of not providing those incentives.”

In DuPont's case, for instance, those state payouts played a significant role in retaining a corporation that has been synonymous with Delaware for two centuries.

Losing the company would have meant more than additional job losses. DuPont has been synonymous with Delaware for more than two centuries, providing not just tens of thousands of jobs, but building roads, supporting charities and providing for its extended family. Few people in Delaware are not touched in some way by the company.

To lose it would have been a psychological blow.

"DuPont was clear to us that this was a business decision and that company leadership had a duty to do what was in the best interest of shareholders," said Bernice Whaley, director of the Delaware Economic Development Office. "So if they were to choose Delaware, they would need us to put forth a package that then allowed them to justify their decision to shareholders."

Big money for big companies

Some of the nation’s largest corporations have received some of the biggest payouts from Delaware's Strategic Fund, a pot of money set aside to provide incentives for job creation and capital development.

Six Fortune 500 companies are among the 10 biggest recipients of those funds since 2009, according to an analysis by The News Journal.

Delaware has committed about $92 million to those six businesses since Gov. Jack Markell took office – that is 37 percent of the roughly $250 million in Strategic Fund grants and loans awarded by his administration.

In November, for instance, JPMorgan Chase secured $10.5 million in state grants to support an expansion that promises to bring 1,800 new jobs to Delaware.

The deal brought the state’s total commitment to JPMorgan over the past three years to more than $22 million, making the nation’s largest bank the second-largest recipient of Strategic Fund dollars under Markell.

Those payouts helped encourage JPMorgan to grow its local workforce from about 6,600 in 2012 to roughly 8,700 today – making the bank Delaware's second-largest private employer behind Christiana Care.

"Our firm is extremely appreciative of the supportive business climate in Delaware, and that’s a big reason why we have chosen to expand and invest here," spokesman Paul Hartwick said. "We have grown significantly in Delaware over the last five years, and we believe the broader community has benefitted from our growth and investments."

Last year, JPMorgan hit record profits of $24.4 billion. Delaware’s operating budget, by comparison, is $3.9 billion.

Citing those massive profits, the Delaware Coalition for Open Government asked the bank to withdraw its most recent application for state support.

“We don’t have a problem with the Strategic Fund in general,” spokesman John Flaherty said. “Our issue is that it’s used to subsidize financial institutions that obviously don’t need these grants.”

Amazon in 2011 received nearly $3.5 million in state incentives, along with a 10-year municipal tax break, to support its 1.2-million-square-foot distribution center in Middletown. The deal was tied to the creation of 850 jobs. Amazon, which recorded $596 million in 2015 profits, does not release specific hiring numbers, but is believed to have roughly 2,500 workers at its Middletown plant today.

JPMorgan Chase adding 1,800 jobs

DuPont and the Dow Chemical Co. are now poised to collect $21 million in state and county grants over the next five years as an enticement for keeping their post-merger agriculture unit in Delaware.

DuPont earned nearly $2 billion in profits in 2015, while Dow raked in nearly $11 billion.

Whaley said closing those incentives off to major corporations would mean closing the state off to the jobs they bring.

DEDO's active portfolio – deals in which benchmarks are still being monitored – has disbursed $92.1 million, with $39.5 million left to be distributed.

To date, those payouts to 500 businesses have led to the creation and retention of nearly 32,300 jobs – about 6,500 more than were promised, the agency says. That's a working population similar in size to the entire population of Newark at an average cost to taxpayers of about $2,850 per job.

“[Markell] has discussed with other governors their mutual dislike of employment incentives,” Whaley said. “But as long as there are states that give these kinds of incentives, then Delaware must do so.”

Some might call that corporate welfare.

John Stapleford, who heads the libertarian-minded Caesar Rodney Institute, likens it more to bribes and ransom.

But even he concedes state incentives are so widespread that they now amount to the cost of doing business.

“States are caught between a rock and a hard place,” he said.

“It’s chump change to these companies, but if you don’t throw something on the table, it looks like you don’t care and that could kill a deal.”

The state of economic development

Economic development incentives are nothing new and their use extends well beyond Delaware.

“Some use more and some use less, but I can’t think of any states that don’t use them at all,” said Bartik, who has authored several research papers on the topic. “It’s not even a liberal or conservative issue at this point.”

Blue states like New York and New Jersey offer some of the biggest incentives, along with red states like Texas and Louisiana.

Even states that once avoided using incentives have been lured in by the promise of jobs.

Minnesota Gov. Mark Dayton, a Democrat, created its first grant program tied to job creation in 2013. The program, capped at $2 million per award, committed to more than $13 million in grants the first year as part of an effort to create nearly 1,400 jobs at 26 businesses, according to media reports.

Since Republican Gov. Brian Sandoval took office in 2011, Nevada has twice broken its record for incentives, packages that rely on targeted tax breaks instead of grants. More recently, Nevada approved a 20-year, $1.2 billion package in 2014 to land a Tesla battery factory, plus a $43 million deal to buy an existing road through a private industrial center.

At least 10 states have approved economic development packages of $1 billion or more, according to Good Jobs First, a labor-backed nonprofit that analyzes tax incentives.

Inside Nevada's $1.25 billion Tesla tax deal

“Most of these things got started back when the South was attempting to attract industry after World War II,” Bartik said. “It then intensified with each economic downturn through the '70s, '80s and '90s.”

Delaware’s Strategic Fund dates back to the mid-1990s under then-Gov. Tom Carper.

At the time, Playtex Products was being courted to relocate its Dover tampon manufacturing plant to Richmond, Virginia, by a promise of $6 million in incentives.

Delaware’s economic development director recommended the state counter with a $3 million cash payment to the company.

Now known as Edgewell Personal Care, the plant is still operating in Dover, where the company employs about 500 workers.

Another 250 new jobs are expected to be added at the site by 2017 thanks to its consolidation with a Montreal plant – a move facilitated by a $3 million Strategic Fund grant approved last year.

A risky game

Like most states, Delaware’s track record with high-dollar grants and loans for major corporations has been spotty, at best.

The First State’s most notorious bust came in the form of a $12.5 million loan and a $9 million grant to Fisker Automotive, marking the third-largest Strategic Fund outlay under Markell.

At the time, the California-based electric car maker was planning to build its Atlantic automobile line at General Motors’ shuttered Boxwood Road plant near Newport, a project that promised to bring more than 2,000 jobs.

Levin: Fisker could return to Delaware

Fisker never built a car in Delaware.

Months of missteps cost the company access to a federal loan, leading the car maker to file for bankruptcy protection in 2013.

Only a small amount of the state’s money was returned.

More recently, Bloom Energy has come under fire for missing hiring benchmarks the company agreed to in 2012 when it received a $16.5 million grant tied to the creation of 900 jobs at its Newark manufacturing plant.

Bloom Energy, which relies on revenue from Delmarva Power surcharges, has blamed its slow growth on regulatory hurdles.

DEDO has given Bloom until 2017 to make up any hiring shortfalls before being required to repay the state grant.

DEDO also extended the deadline for specialty chemical maker Ashland to reach employment benchmarks set in 2012 when the state committed $10 million in grants tied to the creation and retention of 800 jobs.

Since then, Ashland has sold its Delaware-based water technologies unit and paid back the roughly $334,800 received from the state.

DEDO, meanwhile, extended $1.1 million in grants last year to Solenis, the new name of the Ashland spinout.

“The truth is those examples are all pretty typical,” said Jonathan Justice, a public policy professor at UD. “Everyone has similar success or failure rates when it comes to these incentives and I don’t see anything that would suggest Delaware’s record is any worse than other states.”

A questionable practice

A mounting body of evidence indicates few, if any, of the incentives offered by states are achieving their goals.

“The latest studies suggest the probability of these packages being the decisive factor in where a company locates is about 5 to 10 percent,” Bartik said.

A state’s business climate, tax codes, regulatory structure, labor force and education systems are given considerably more weight by companies looking to move or grow their business operations, he said.

“There are much bigger reasons why a company chooses where to locate and it ain’t $10 million to $20 million in one-time money,” Singleton said. “It would be a real embarrassment if these executives had to explain to their shareholders why they stayed or moved to a state and the answer was because they bribed you.”

Singleton, who served as chief of staff to Wilmington’s mayor William T. McLaughlin from the late 1970s to the early 1980s, recently penned a column in The News Journal lamenting his role in helping to create what he says has become an incentive “monster.”

The city’s incentive program pre-dates the state's, beginning in 1977 with a loan to the developers of a Doubletree Hotel, followed years later with a deal to keep Hercules Inc. in downtown Wilmington.

“Back then, incentives were a difference-maker because they weren’t available everywhere,” he said. “Now it’s an arms race with every state and most cities offering bigger and bigger deals because no one wants to call these corporations on their bluff.”

A 2013 report by Good Jobs First found both the number of so-called “megadeals” – packages valued at more than $75 million – doubled nationwide in six years.

Carper, for instance, used a $40.7 million package of grants and tax credits, along with $70 million in road improvements to convince the newly formed AstraZeneca to establish its North American headquarters in Fairfax in 1999. In exchange, AstraZeneca pledged to increase its workforce at the site from 2,400 to 4,000 by 2004.

The pharmaceutical company's employment hit a peak of 5,000 workers in 2005, only to have patent losses and a global recession lead to a major restructuring. Today, AstraZeneca has about 2,400 workers in Delaware.

But the sheer size of those "megadeal" incentives makes it increasingly unlikely states will recoup their investments through future property and payroll tax revenue.

“The problem is states tend to overbid on these projects,” Bartik said. “It’s easier to explain why they paid so much to win a company than to explain why they didn’t after losing out to another state.”

An incentive for reform

Concerns over whether ballooning incentive payouts are justified – and actually creating the jobs they promise – have led many states, including Delaware, to re-examine their programs.

Some have started cutting back on incentives, imposing stricter accountability measures and responding to calls for increased transparency.

“Some places don’t have any guidelines for achieving a return on investment,” Bartik said. “If there aren’t any rules, how can you have any limits?”

A 2014 report by Good Jobs First ranked Delaware and three other states among the worst in terms of providing taxpayers with details about their economic development incentives.

For Delaware, $200M in corporate giveaways, little transparency

Delaware offers virtually no reports of actual job creation numbers online and no independent evaluations are conducted to determine the state’s return on investment.

Those issues helped lead the General Assembly’s Joint Sunset committee to review DEDO’s performance over objections from the Markell administration.

That 2015 review resulted in passage of a bill, later signed by the governor, that made small changes to DEDO’s reporting requirements.

The legislation required new annual reports on the incentives provided and jobs promised, but not actual jobs created. The first of those reports was released in December.

The measure also requires DEDO to develop a five-year comprehensive plan that details actual job creation and return on investment, along with the office’s strategies and objectives related to specific business sectors.

The first of those plans is due in 2019 – two years after Markell leaves office.

Delaware jobs grants get more transparency

The governor, in recent years, also has cut funding for the Strategic Fund.

Markell in 2015 set aside $10 million to cover incentives for the fiscal year that began July 1, a 48 percent cut from the previous year. And his budget proposal for the coming fiscal year would hold the funding at the same amount.

Despite questions of their true effectiveness, Whaley said Delaware’s use of incentives has been successful because it pursues the biggest bang for the buck.

“We are competing against 49 other states, many of which have more resources than we do and are willing to spend more per capita than we do,” she said. “In order to maximize our chances of success, we have to be willing to compete for jobs from big and small companies.”

No end in sight

While the use of incentives may be a factor in that job creation, it’s also possible investing those funds in other areas would pay larger dividends, Bartik said.

A portion of the incentive package offered to DuPont and Dow, for example, includes $3.6 million in grants to support the creation of 400 jobs.

“You could achieve the same magnitude by offering 200 small businesses $1,800 a year for the next five years to each add two new jobs,” he said. “The state investment would be the same but that kind of money would certainly be more impactful to those companies.”

Leaders in the state’s bioscience industry called for exactly those kind of investments last year.

“If your focus is on high-paying jobs that tend to more broadly support the locally economy, there are also other investments you could be making,” he said. “Customized job training, business incubators or simply investing in education, in the long run, would make a state more attract to employers.”

The problem, he said, is that no state wants to take the risk of giving up its economic incentive programs.

“Once you’ve started down that road, how do you turn back,” he asked. “In the [European Union], these kinds of incentives are illegal, but it would take federal legislation to put a stop to it here, and I don’t see that happening any time soon.”

States now have little choice other than to keep playing a game everyone knows is flawed, Butkiewicz said.

“If everyone stopped, it wouldn’t have any impact on the overall economy because companies would still move,” he said. “But if Delaware stopped on its own, I imagine it would lose out on every one of those deals.”

Contact business reporter Scott Goss at (302) 324-2281, sgoss@delawareonline.com or on Twitter @ScottGossDel.
